Glut 4, the insulin-responsive glucose transporter isoform, is expressed primarily in muscle and adipose tissue. In the basal state, Glut 4-containing vesicles cycle slowly between the plasma membrane and intracellular compartments, with the vast majority of the Glut 4 sequestrated within intracellular compartments. Insulin triggers a large increase in the rate of Glut 4-containing vesicles exocytosis, resulting in the accumulation of the transporter at the cell surface and concomitant increase in glucose uptake (1Thurmond D.C. Pessin J.E. Mol. Membr. Biol. 2001; 18: 237-245Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 2Holman G.D. Sandoval I.V. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 173-179Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Insulin effect on glucose uptake requires the tyrosine phosphorylation of IRS-1 (insulin receptorsubstrate-1) and the activation of PI3K 1The abbreviations used are: PI3K, phosphoinositide 3-kinase; SH2, Src homology 2; PLC, phospholipase C; ERK, extracellular signal-regulated kinase; SNARE, solubleN-ethymaleimide-sensitive fusion protein attachment protein receptor; DMEM, Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; EGFP, enhanced green fluorescent protein and its effector, the protein serine/threonine kinase B (3Saltiel A.R. Pessin J.E. Trends Cell Biol. 2002; 12: 65-71Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (507) Google Scholar). However, some data indicate that insulin should also activate a PI3K-independent pathway to produce its full effect (4Baumann C.A. Ribon V. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Mora S. Shigematsu S. Bickel P.E. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2000; 407: 202-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (564) Google Scholar, 5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar). Indeed, in adipocytes, the Cbl proto-oncogene, associated with CAP (Cbl-associated protein) and APS (adapter protein containing PH andSH2 domain) is phosphorylated in response to insulin and regulates glucose uptake (4Baumann C.A. Ribon V. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Mora S. Shigematsu S. Bickel P.E. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2000; 407: 202-207Crossref PubMed Scopus (564) Google Scholar, 6Ahmed Z. Smith B.J. Pillay T.S. FEBS Lett. 2000; 475: 31-34Crossref PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Once phosphorylated, Cbl recruits the adapter protein Crk-II in a complex with C3G, a GDP to GTP exchange factor for TC10, a Rho-family GTPase, allowing for its activation, which regulates the traffic of Glut 4-containing vesicles (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar). However, it has not been determined yet whether the Glut 4 translocation induced by other stimuli, such as osmotic shock, also required the activation of the Crk-II/TC10 pathway. Osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation is not due to IRS-1 tyrosine phosphorylation and is largely PI3K/protein kinase B-independent (7Meier R. Thelen M. Hemmings B.A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 7294-7303Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 8Chen D. Fucini R.V. Olson A.L. Hemmings B.A. Pessin J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4684-4694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), but it requires the activation of a tyrosine kinase signaling pathway (9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar). Among the proteins phosphorylated on tyrosine following osmotic shock stimulation, Gab-1 (Grb2-associatedbinder-1) seems to play a key role, because microinjection of anti-Gab-1 antibodies strongly inhibits osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation without altering insulin effect (10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Gab-1 is an adapter protein that possesses an N-terminal pleckstrin homology domain and 16 potential tyrosine phosphorylation sites (11Holgado-Madruga M. Emlet D.R. Moscatello D.K. Godwin A.K. Wong A.J. Nature. 1996; 379: 560-564Crossref PubMed Scopus (603) Google Scholar, 12Weidner K.M. DiCesare S. Sachs M. Brinkmann V. Behrens J. Birchmeier W. Nature. 1996; 384: 173-176Crossref PubMed Scopus (507) Google Scholar). Upon phosphorylation, some of them could generate binding sites for SH2-containing proteins such as PI3K, SHPTP-2 (SH2-containing phosphotyrosinephosphatase-2), Crk-II, and PLCγ1 (13Holgado-Madruga M. Moscatello D.K. Emlet D.R. Dieterich R. Wong A.J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 12419-12424Crossref PubMed Scopus (229) Google Scholar, 14Garcia-Guzman M. Dolfi F. Zeh K. Vuori K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7775-7786Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar, 15Gual P. Giordano S. Williams T.A. Rocchi S. Van Obberghen E. Comoglio P.M. Oncogene. 2000; 19: 1509-1518Crossref PubMed Scopus (138) Google Scholar). However, there are few insights into signaling pathways downstream of Gab-1 involved in osmotic shock-induced glucose uptake. In the present study, we show that in response to osmotic shock, Gab-1 acts as a docking protein for PLCγ1, the p85 subunit of PI3K, and Crk-II. Although PI3K and PLCγ1 activation are not required for glucose transport, we found that the newly identified Crk-II/TC10 signaling pathway plays an important role in osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation and glucose transport. Further, our data suggest that the regulation of cortical actin remodeling is also necessary for Glut 4 translocation in response to osmotic shock. Enhanced chemiluminescence reagent was purchased from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. 3T3-L1 fibroblasts were grown in 35- or 100-mm dishes in DMEM, 25 mm glucose, 10% calf serum and induced to differentiate in adipocytes as described previously (19Student A.K. Hsu R.Y. Lane M.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1980; 255: 4745-4750Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, 2 days after confluence, medium was changed for DMEM, 25 mmglucose, 10% fetal calf serum supplemented with isobutylmethylxanthine (0.25 mm), dexamethasone (0.25 μm), Thiazolidinediones (10 μm) (compound 57135; Servier, Suresnes, France) and insulin (5 μg/ml). The medium was removed after 2 days and replaced with DMEM, 25 mm glucose, 10% fetal calf serum supplemented with insulin for 2 more days. Then, the cells were fed every 2 days with DMEM, 25 mm glucose, 10% fetal calf serum. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were used 8–15 days after the beginning of the differentiation protocol. Sixteen h before each experiment, the medium was changed to serum-free DMEM supplemented with 0.5% bovine serum albumin. After serum starvation, 3T3-L1 adipocytes were incubated with sorbitol (600 mm) for different periods of times. Cells were washed subsequently with ice-cold buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 150 mmNaCl, 5 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaF, and 2 mm sodium orthovanadate) before solubilization for 30 min at 4 °C in lysis buffer (20 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm EDTA, 150 mm NaF, 2 mm sodium orthovanadate, 0.5 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, proteases inhibitors, and 1% Triton X-100). Lysates obtained after centrifugation (15 min at 15,000 ×g at 4 °C) were incubated for 3 h at 4 °C with appropriate antibodies preadsorbed on protein G-Sepharose (4 μg of antibodies/sample). Following washes with lysis buffer, immune pellets were resuspended in Laemmli buffer, and proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE using a 7.5 or 10% resolving gel, before transfer to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. The membrane was blocked with saline buffer (10 mm Tris, pH 7.4, 140 mm NaCl) containing 5% (w/v) bovine serum albumin for 2 h at room temperature and blotted overnight at 4 °C with antibodies against phosphotyrosine, PLCγ1, Gab-1, Crk-II, or the p85 subunit of PI3K at the dilution indicated by the manufacturer's instructions. Following incubation with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies, proteins were detected by enhanced chemiluminescence. In some cases, the membrane was stripped for 30 min at 50 °C in 62 mmTris, pH 6.7, 100 mm 2-mercaptoethanol, and 2% SDS and reprobed with the indicated antibodies. After serum starvation, 3T3-L1 adipocytes were incubated or not with the different inhibitors at the concentration and for the time indicated in the legend to figures. Cells were then washed with Krebs-Ringer phosphate buffer (10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, 1 mmMgSO4, 1 mm CaCl2, 136 mm NaCl, 4.7 mm KCl) and incubated without or with sorbitol (600 mm) for 20 min in Krebs-Ringer phosphate buffer supplemented with 0.1% bovine serum albumin. Glucose transport was determined by the addition of 2-[3H]deoxyglucose (0.1 mm, 0.5 μCi/ml) as described previously (20Tanti J.F. Grémeaux T. Van Obberghen E. Le Marchand-Brustel Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 6051-6057Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The reaction was stopped after 3 min by aspiration, and cells were washed four times with ice-cold PBS. Cells were lysed in Krebs-Ringer phosphate, 1% Triton X-100, and glucose uptake was assessed by scintillation counting. Results were normalized for protein measured by BCA assay. Nine to ten days post-differentiation, 3T3-L1 adipocytes were electroporated with plasmid coding for Glut 4-EGFP (50 μg) and empty plasmid (200 μg) or plasmid coding for Myc-tagged wild-type TC10, constitutively active TC10/Q75L, or dominant-negative TC10/T31N (200 μg) using a low voltage electroporation technique as described previously (21Watson R.T. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 1261-1268Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). After 18 h, 3T3-L1 adipocytes were placed in DMEM, 25 mm glucose, 0.1% bovine serum albumin for 2h at 37 °C. Then, the cells were incubated with or without insulin (100 nm) or sorbitol (600 mm) for 30 min at 37 °C. The cells were washed once with ice-cold PBS and fixed with 4% paraformaldehyde (Electron Microscopy Sciences, Ft. Washington, PA) for 10 min at room temperature. After being washed, the cells were permeabilized with PBS containing 0.2% Triton X-100 at room temperature for 10 min and blocked with PBS, 0.2% Triton X-100, 5% donkey serum. The cells expressing Myc-tagged TC10/T31N were detected following incubation with anti-c-Myc antibodies for 90 min at 37 °C and Texas Red-conjugated donkey secondary antibody (Jackson Immunoresearch Laboratories, West Grove, PA) for 2 h at room temperature. The coverslips were mounted in Vectashield (Vector Laboratories, Inc., Burlington, CA) and examined by a confocal laser-scanning microscope. Quantification of the number of cells displaying Glut 4-EGFP plasma membrane fluorescence was determined from the counting of 80 cells that were co-expressing both Myc-tagged TC10/T31N and Glut 4-EGFP in three independent experiments. Cells with a continuous fluorescent rim are considered as positive for Glut 4 translocation. By contrast, they are considered as negative when the labeling is absent, discontinuous, or when it appears as punctate structures. Because Gab-1 is tyrosine-phosphorylated in response to osmotic shock and plays an important role in the stimulation of Glut 4 translocation and glucose transport (10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we investigated which proteins were associated with tyrosine-phosphorylated Gab-1. Gab-1 was immunoprecipitated from 3T3-L1 adipocytes treated or not with 600 mm sorbitol for various periods of time, and its tyrosine phosphorylation was analyzed by Western blotting with phosphotyrosine antibodies. As shown in Fig.1 A, sorbitol treatment induced a transient tyrosine phosphorylation of Gab-1, which was maximal between 10 and 20 min and declined thereafter. We also detected the tyrosine phosphorylation of one protein at 145 kDa co-immunoprecipitated with Gab-1. Because Gab-1 possesses several potential docking sites for the p85 subunit of PI3K and PLCγ1, we investigated whether both proteins bound to tyrosine-phosphorylated Gab-1. As shown in Fig. 1 A, sorbitol stimulation induced a large increase in the coimmunoprecipitation of both p85 and PLCγ1 with Gab-1 indicating that this association is a tyrosine phosphorylation-dependent process. Because PLCγ1 activation is correlated with its phosphorylation (22Kim H.K. Kim J.W. Zilberstein A. Margolis B. Kim J.G. Schlessinger J. Rhee S.G. Cell. 1991; 65: 435-441Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar), we then determined whether PLCγ1 was tyrosine-phosphorylated in response to sorbitol. As shown in Fig. 1 B, we observed an increase of the tyrosine phosphorylation of PLCγ1 upon sorbitol stimulation. Therefore, the protein with a molecular mass of 145 kDa associated with Gab-1 and phosphorylated on tyrosine residue in response to sorbitol likely corresponds to PLCγ1. We then tested whether PI3K or PLCγ1 activation was required for osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were pretreated with a PI3K inhibitor (wortmannin 100 nm) or a PLC inhibitor (U73122; 10 μm) before stimulation with sorbitol (600 mm) for 30 min. Deoxyglucose uptake was then measured. We observed that inhibition of PI3K activity by wortmannin did not block the effect of sorbitol on glucose uptake as described previously (9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar,23Sakaue H. Ogawa W. Takata M. Kuroda S. Kotani K. Matsumoto M. Sakaue M. Nishio S. Ueno H. Kasuga M. Mol. Endocrinol. 1997; 11: 1552-1562Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). Inhibition of PLC by U73122 did not affect sorbitol-induced glucose transport (Fig. 2 A) although the sorbitol-mediated mitogen-activated protein kinase activation was inhibited (Fig. 2 B) as reported previously for insulin (24Kayali A.G. Eichhorn J. Haruta T. Morris A.J. Nelson J.G. Vollenweider P. Olefsky J.M. Webster N.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 13808-13818Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). To demonstrate further that PLCγ1-dependent pathways are not required for this biological response, we prevented the activation of either protein kinase C by staurosporine (214 nm) or α-diacylglycerol kinase by R59949 (10 μm) before the glucose uptake assay. As shown in Fig. 2 A, pretreatment of 3T3-L1 adipocytes with these inhibitors did not modify the sorbitol effect on glucose transport. Further, ERK pathways are not involved in osmotic shock-induced glucose transport, because both a mitogen-activated protein kinase/extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase 1 inhibitor (PD98059) and U73122 did not prevent sorbitol-induced glucose transport (Fig. 2 A). Taken together, these data indicate that PI3K, PLCγ1, and ERK pathways are not involved in osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. The above data led us to search for other proteins that could bind to Gab-1 and play a role in this metabolic effect. Gab-1 possesses binding sites for the SH2-containing protein Crk-II (14Garcia-Guzman M. Dolfi F. Zeh K. Vuori K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7775-7786Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar), which is involved in the stimulation of Glut 4 translocation in response to insulin (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar). To investigate whether Crk-II could form a complex with Gab-1 in response to sorbitol, Crk-II was immunoprecipitated from lysates of 3T3-L1 adipocytes treated or not with sorbitol (600 mm) for various periods of time, and the presence of Gab-1 was detected with specific antibodies. As shown in Fig. 3 A, upon osmotic shock stimulation, an association between Gab-1 and Crk-II was detected, which correlated directly with the tyrosine phosphorylation state of Gab-1 shown previously. It should be noted that sorbitol stimulation also led to a reduction in the electrophoretic mobility of Crk-II (Fig.3, A and B), which could be because of an increase in its tyrosine phosphorylation (data not shown). Moreover, the time course of Gab-1/Crk-II association is compatible with glucose uptake induced by osmotic shock (Fig. 3 C), because this association was maximal already after 10 min of stimulation. The Gab-1-Crk signaling complex formation has been involved in the activation of small GTP-binding proteins in response to growth factor (14Garcia-Guzman M. Dolfi F. Zeh K. Vuori K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7775-7786Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar, 25Sakkab D. Lewitzky M. Posern G. Schaeper U. Sachs M. Birchmeier W. Feller S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10772-10778Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). Indeed, Crk-II is associated constitutively with C3G (26Feller S.M. Oncogene. 2001; 20: 6348-6371Crossref PubMed Scopus (419) Google Scholar), a GDP to GTP exchange factor for several small GTP-binding proteins including some members of the Rho family (27Watson R.T. Pessin J.E. Exp. Cell Res. 2001; 271: 75-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Because the Rho family plays a role in insulin-induced Glut 4 translocation (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar), we investigated whether glucose transport induced by osmotic shock is dependent on these proteins. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were pretreated with C. difficile toxin B (1 μg/ml), which inactivates members of the Rho family proteins (16Just I. Fritz G. Aktories K. Giry M. Popoff M.R. Boquet P. Hegenbarth S. von Eichel-Streiber C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 10706-10712Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Just I. Selzer J. von Eichel-Streiber C. Aktories K. J. Clin. Invest. 1995; 95: 1026-1031Crossref PubMed Scopus (100) Google Scholar, 18Just I. Selzer J. Wilm M. von Eichel-Streiber C. Mann M. Aktories K. Nature. 1995; 375: 500-503Crossref PubMed Scopus (885) Google Scholar), before measuring glucose uptake in response to sorbitol (600 mm). As shown in Fig.4, inactivation of the Rho family proteins partially inhibited osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. These results suggest that at least one small GTP-binding protein of the Rho family is involved in osmotic shock signaling for glucose transport. We next attempted to identify the member of the Rho GTPase family involved in osmotic shock-mediated glucose transport. Because activation of the Rho GTP-binding protein TC10 is required for insulin-induced Glut 4 translocation (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar), we investigated its role in osmotic shock-mediated Glut 4 translocation. 3T3-L1 adipocytes overexpressing Glut 4-EGFP alone or with various Myc-tagged TC10 proteins were left untreated or stimulated with sorbitol (600 mm) or insulin (100 nm) for 30 min. The cell expressing Myc-tagged TC10/T31N, the dominant interfering mutant of TC10, were then identified by immunofluorescence with anti-Myc antibodies (Fig.5), and the subcellular localization of Glut 4-EGFP was evaluated by confocal fluorescent microscopy as described under “Experimental Procedures.” As shown in Fig. 5, in both cell lines, Glut 4-EGFP was localized mainly inside the cells in control conditions. In cells expressing Glut 4-EGFP alone, insulin and sorbitol induced the appearance of a plasma membrane Glut 4-EGFP rim fluorescence, indicative of translocation of Glut 4-EGFP. However, quantification of the number of cells displaying a continuous cell surface Glut 4-EGFP fluorescence rim demonstrated that sorbitol treatment was less effective than insulin in stimulating Glut 4-EGFP translocation (Fig. 6 A). This is in agreement with the fact that osmotic shock is less efficient than insulin to mediate glucose uptake (8Chen D. Fucini R.V. Olson A.L. Hemmings B.A. Pessin J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4684-4694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In cells expressing both Glut 4-EGFP and TC10/T31N, osmotic shock-induced Glut 4-EGFP translocation was inhibited substantially as visualized by the absence of cells showing a continuous cell surface Glut 4-EGFP fluorescence rim (see Fig. 5 and Fig. 6). The same method was used to assess the effect of wild-type or constitutively active form (TC10/Q75L) of TC10 on osmotic shock-induced Glut 4-EGFP translocation. In contrast to TC10/T31N, wild-type TC10 or TC10/Q75L only had a small inhibitory effect on osmotic shock-stimulated Glut 4-EGFP translocation (Fig.6 B). By contrast, and as described previously (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar), insulin-induced Glut 4 translocation was inhibited by 60% in cells expressing TC10/T31N compared with control cells (see Fig. 5 and Fig.6 A). These data are consistent with a requirement of the TC10 signaling pathway in the osmotic shock stimulation of Glut 4 translocation.Figure 6Effect of different forms of TC10 on osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation. 3T3-L1 adipocytes were treated as described in the legend for Fig. 5. A, quantification of the number of cells displaying Glut 4-EGFP plasma membrane fluorescence was determined from the counting of 80 cells that were coexpressing both Myc-tagged TC10/T31N and Glut 4-EGFP in three independent experiments. B, quantification of the number of cells displaying Glut 4-EGFP plasma membrane fluorescence was determined from the counting of 80 cells that were coexpressing both Glut 4-EGFP and Myc-tagged wild-type TC10 (TC10 wt) or TC10/T31N or TC10/Q75L in three independent experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) TC10 activation could be involved in cortical actin remodeling, which seems essential for the insulin-stimulated Glut 4 translocation process (28Kanzaki M. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 42436-42444Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar). To assess a possible involvement of actin in the Glut 4 translocation in response to osmotic shock, we preincubated 3T3-L1 adipocytes with either latrunculin B (10 μm), an agent that sequesters actin monomers, or jasplakinolide (10 μm), a stabilizer of filamentous actin. As shown in Fig. 7 A, latrunculin B or jasplakinolide decreased osmotic shock-stimulated glucose transport by 57 and 51%, respectively. It is important to note that latrunculin B did not alter the ability of osmotic shock to promote the tyrosine phosphorylation of Gab-1 (Fig. 7 B) and its association with Crk-II (Fig. 7 C), thus ruling out an early inhibition of proximal osmotic shock signaling events. The previous series of experiments indicate that cortical actin integrity is necessary for osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. It has been described recently (29Kanzaki M. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 25867-25869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar) that unique cortical filamentous actin structures, designated Cav-actin (for caveolin-associated F-actin) are present in differentiated 3T3-L1 adipocytes. These structures are visible in the merged image of Fig.8 (top panel) on the bottom of the cell. Individual caveolae are clustered into ring-like arrays (“caveolae-rosettes”), and these structures are also positive for actin, which is labeled with phalloidin. Osmotic shock markedly increased cortical actin, particularly visible at the bottom of the cell, in contact with the substratum. This effect was sensitive to toxin B and latrunculin but not wortmannin (data not shown). Further, there was a dramatic increase in the amount of F-actin associated with caveolin in these large Cav-actin structures (Fig. 8,lower panel). These results show that osmotic shock regulation of cortical actin rearrangements appears necessary for glucose transport, which could occur through a TC10- dependent pathway. In 3T3-L1 adipocytes, osmotic shock triggers the cell surface accumulation of Glut 4 leading to glucose uptake by mechanisms, which have not yet been elucidated fully. It has been shown that this process is largely PI3K/protein kinase B-independent (7Meier R. Thelen M. Hemmings B.A. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 7294-7303Crossref PubMed Scopus (149) Google Scholar, 8Chen D. Fucini R.V. Olson A.L. Hemmings B.A. Pessin J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4684-4694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 23Sakaue H. Ogawa W. Takata M. Kuroda S. Kotani K. Matsumoto M. Sakaue M. Nishio S. Ueno H. Kasuga M. Mol. Endocrinol. 1997; 11: 1552-1562Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar, 30Barros L.F. Barnes K. Ingram J. Castro J. Porras O.H. Baldwin S.A. Pflugers Arch. 2001; 442: 614-621Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar) but requires a tyrosine kinase activity different from the insulin receptor kinase (8Chen D. Fucini R.V. Olson A.L. Hemmings B.A. Pessin J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4684-4694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar). Osmotic shock induces the tyrosine phosphorylation of the docking protein Gab-1, which plays a major role in osmotic shock signal transduction pathways involved in glucose transport (10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In the present study, we have investigated the role of different signaling pathways downstream of Gab-1 in the induction of this biological response. Gab-1 contains several potential binding sites for SH2-containing proteins including the p85 subunit of the PI3K, PLCγ and Crk-II. We show that the association between tyrosine-phosphorylated Gab-1 and these proteins is increased in 3T3-L1 adipocytes upon osmotic shock stimulation. Further, we observe an increase in the tyrosine phosphorylation of PLCγ, which is linked to its activation (22Kim H.K. Kim J.W. Zilberstein A. Margolis B. Kim J.G. Schlessinger J. Rhee S.G. Cell. 1991; 65: 435-441Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (448) Google Scholar). However, in contrast to recent data (31Ueno E. Haruta T. Uno T. Usui I. Iwata M. Takano A. Kawahara J. Sasaoka T. Ishibashi O. Kobayashi M. Horm. Metab. Res. 2001; 33: 402-406Crossref PubMed Scopus (7) Google Scholar), our results are not in favor of a role of PLCγ in osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. Indeed, inhibition of PLC by U73122 did not change the effect of osmotic shock on glucose transport, whereas activation of ERK was prevented as reported previously for insulin (24Kayali A.G. Eichhorn J. Haruta T. Morris A.J. Nelson J.G. Vollenweider P. Olefsky J.M. Webster N.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 13808-13818Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). This indicates that this inhibitor effectively blocks PLC activity. Further, we show that inhibition of signaling pathway downstream of PLCγ, including protein kinase C and α-diacylglycerol kinase activity, has no effect on osmotic shock-induced glucose uptake. Although PI3K and PLCγ do not seem to be involved in glucose transport, they could be implicated in other effects of hyperosmolarity. For instance, PI3K activation is required for osmotic shock-induced membrane ruffling (10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Because PLCγ mediates ERK activation in response to sorbitol treatment, it is also likely that hyperosmolarity-induced PLCγ activation is involved in modification of gene expression (32Kultz D. Chakravarty D. Comp. Biochem. Physiol. 2001; 130: 421-428Crossref Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Osmotic shock also promotes the association between Gab-1 and Crk-II. Thus, we investigated the significance of this complex formation in osmotic shock signaling. Crk-II is an adapter protein that can constitutively bind C3G (26Feller S.M. Oncogene. 2001; 20: 6348-6371Crossref PubMed Scopus (419) Google Scholar), a GDP to GTP exchange factor for several small GTP-binding proteins including members of the Rho family (27Watson R.T. Pessin J.E. Exp. Cell Res. 2001; 271: 75-83Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Further, several reports have demonstrated that the Gab-1-Crk signaling complex formation in response to growth factor correlates directly with activation of small GTP-binding proteins (14Garcia-Guzman M. Dolfi F. Zeh K. Vuori K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 7775-7786Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar, 25Sakkab D. Lewitzky M. Posern G. Schaeper U. Sachs M. Birchmeier W. Feller S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 10772-10778Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (117) Google Scholar). Binding of Crk-II to Gab-1 in response to osmotic shock could thus lead to an accumulation of C3G near the plasma membrane where it may exert its effect on small GTP-binding proteins of the Rho family. It has been shown recently that C3G efficiently catalyzes the exchange of GDP to GTP on TC10, a member of the Rho family. Activation of this GTPase plays a critical role in insulin-induced Glut 4 translocation (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar). This prompted us to investigate whether TC10 was also involved in osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. We found that (i) inactivation of the Rho family proteins by C. difficile toxin B inhibited osmotic shock-stimulated glucose uptake, and (ii) the overexpression of the dominant-interfering TC10/T31N blocked the accumulation of Glut 4 to the cell membrane, whereas wild-type or constitutively active TC10 had a small, if any, inhibitory effect. Taken together, these results are in favor of a role of TC10 in the regulation of Glut 4 trafficking in response to osmotic shock. Glut 4 accumulation at the cell surface is because of the stimulation of its translocation from its sequestration compartment and/or from an inhibition of its endocytosis. In L6 muscle cells, the increase in Glut 4 amount at the cell surface in response to osmotic shock results from the prevention of its endocytosis and the stimulation of its exocytosis. The former is tyrosine kinase-independent, whereas the latter is a tyrosine kinase-dependent process (33Li D. Randhawa V.K. Patel N. Hayashi M. Klip A. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 22883-22891Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). However, in 3T3-L1 adipocytes, the inhibition of tyrosine kinase activity completely blocks hyperosmolarity-induced glucose uptake (9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar, 10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). It is therefore conceivable that Glut 4 endocytosis is not blocked by osmotic shock in 3T3-L1 adipocytes, and Gab-1 and TC10 could regulate Glut 4 exocytosis rather than its endocytosis. Our results also demonstrate that osmotic shock and insulin share the TC10 signaling pathway to stimulate glucose uptake. Activation of TC10 in response to insulin requires the tyrosine phosphorylation of Cbl in complex with CAP, which in turn binds the Crk-II-C3G complex (5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar). Because Cbl is tyrosine-phosphorylated in response to osmotic shock (9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar) and forms a complex with Crk-II (data not shown), we cannot rule out that Cbl could be also involved in osmotic shock-induced TC10 activation. However, signaling pathways downstream of Gab-1 seem to play a major role in osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. Indeed, microinjection of Gab-1 antibodies in 3T3-L1 adipocytes markedly inhibits Glut 4-translocation (10Janez A. Worrall D.S. Imamura T. Sharma P.M. Olefsky J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26870-26876Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A major difference between osmotic shock and insulin in the regulation of glucose uptake is that insulin activates both a PI3K/protein kinase B and a TC10 pathway to fully stimulate Glut 4 translocation. This could explain why overexpression of TC10/T31N only partly inhibited Glut 4 translocation in insulin-treated cells (see Fig. 5 and Ref. 5Chiang S., H Baumann C.A. Kanzaki M. Thurmond D.C. Watson R.T. Neudauer C.L. Macara I.G. Pessin J.E. Saltiel A.R. Nature. 2001; 410: 944-948Crossref PubMed Scopus (484) Google Scholar) and why inhibition of insulin-induced protein kinase B activation by sorbitol induced an insulin-resistant state for glucose transport (8Chen D. Fucini R.V. Olson A.L. Hemmings B.A. Pessin J.E. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 4684-4694Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We thus propose that the TC10 signaling pathway could be shared by different stimuli, which mediate Glut 4 translocation, whereas the PI3K/protein kinase B-dependent pathway would be more specific for insulin action. Because both osmotic shock and insulin appear to require TC10 activation to stimulate Glut 4 translocation, it is tempting to assume that the signaling pathways downstream of TC10 are also shared by these two stimuli. Cortical actin must undergo an active insulin-stimulated remodeling to allow for Glut 4 translocation, which appears to be regulated by TC10 (28Kanzaki M. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 42436-42444Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (232) Google Scholar, 34Kanzaki M. Watson R.T. Khan A.H. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 49331-49336Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (72) Google Scholar). Our data are in favor of a similar regulation for osmotic shock-induced glucose transport. Indeed, disruption of cortical actin integrity by latrunculin B or stabilization of polymerized actin by jasplakinolide inhibits osmotic shock-stimulated glucose transport. Further, osmotic shock increased the appearance of the caveolin-associated filamentous actin structures, which could play a role in Glut 4 translocation (29Kanzaki M. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 2002; 277: 25867-25869Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar). Therefore, cortical actin remodeling, which could be mediated by TC10, appears to be a necessary event induced by different stimuli for Glut 4 translocation and glucose transport. It should be noted that expression of a dominant-interfering mutant of TC10 evoked a greater inhibition of osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation than disruption of cytoskeleton. It is possible that TC10, in addition to its role on cortical actin remodeling, regulates other steps required for Glut 4 translocation. An attractive hypothesis is that TC10 could also regulate the interaction between v-SNARE present on Glut 4-containing vesicles and t-SNARE at the plasma membrane. Indeed, it has been proposed that actin reorganization modulates the redistribution of both Glut 4-containing vesicles and t-SNARE proteins (Syntaxin-4 and SNAP 23 (solubleNSF attachment protein23)) to the same cellular location below the cell surface (35Tong P. Khayat Z.A. Huang C. Patel N. Ueyama A. Klip A. J. Clin. Invest. 2001; 108: 371-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (165) Google Scholar). The actin network could thus serve as scaffolding structures to facilitate the interaction between the Glut 4-containing vesicles and the t-SNARE proteins allowing for the insertion of Glut 4 into the plasma membrane. It has also been proposed that small GTP-binding proteins could regulate the interaction between v- and t-SNARE (36Waters M.G. Hughson F.M. Traffic. 2000; 1: 588-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (91) Google Scholar,37Zhang X., Bi, E. Novick P., Du, L. Kozminski K.G. Lipschutz J.H. Guo W. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 46745-46750Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (250) Google Scholar). Thus, TC10, by regulating both processes (cortical actin remodeling and v-/t-SNARE interaction), could ensure a proper timing allowing for a correct insertion of Glut 4 into the plasma membrane in response to both insulin and osmotic shock stimulation. In agreement with this hypothesis, it has been shown that the t-SNARE protein syntaxin-4 is required for docking/fusion of Glut 4-containing vesicles in response to both osmotic shock and insulin (9Chen D. Elmendorf J.S. Olson A.L., Li, X. Earp H.S. Pessin J.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27401-27410Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (139) Google Scholar). In summary, our data demonstrate that osmotic shock induces the formation of a signaling complex between Gab-1 and Crk-II, which could lead to the activation of the small GTPase TC10. The activation of TC10 and remodeling of actin structure are required for osmotic shock-induced Glut 4 translocation. Revealing how the TC10 signaling pathway regulates Glut 4 translocation is an important issue for future investigation. We are grateful to Dr. I. Just (Institut fur Pharmakologie und Toxikologie, Universitat Freiburg, Germany) for the gift of Clostridium difficile toxin B and Dr. N. Levens (Servier, Suresnes, France) for the gift of TZD. We thank Drs. E. Lemichez and P. Boquet for help, discussion, and sharing reagents.

Following exposure to genotoxic stress, proliferating cells actively slow down DNA replication through an S phase checkpoint to provide time for repair. The ATM-dependent pathway plays an important role in the S phase checkpoint response following ionizing irradiation. We report that there is a stronger S phase checkpoint response in irradiated Ku80(-/-) cells as compared with their wild-type counterparts, which has no relationship to DNA-dependent protein kinase (DNA-PK) activity but correlates with a higher ATM activity and with more ATM bound to chromatin DNA in such cells. Wortmannin, a nonspecific inhibitor of ATM, not only reduces the higher activity of ATM kinase, but also abolishes the stronger S phase checkpoint response in Ku80(-/-) cells. Furthermore, a specific ATM antisense oligonucleotide abolishes the stronger S checkpoint response in Ku80(-/-) cells and renders these cells practically indistinguishable from Ku80(+/+) cells for this endpoint. These results in aggregate indicate that the stronger S checkpoint in irradiated Ku80(-/-) cells is due to the higher ATM kinase activity.

Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO) is used clinically to treat pulmonary hypertension in newborns, often in conjunction with hyperoxia (NO/O2). Prolonged exposure to NO/O2 causes synergistic lung injury and death of lung epithelial cells. To explore the mechanisms involved, oxygen-resistant HeLa-80 cells were exposed to NO ± O2. Exposure to NO and O2 induced a synergistic cytotoxicity, accompanied with apoptotic characteristics, including elevated caspase-3-like activity, Annexin V incorporation, and nuclear condensation. This apoptosis was associated with a synergistic suppression of NF-κB activity. Cells lacking functional NF-κB p65 subunit were more sensitive to NO/O2 than their wild type counterparts. This injury was partially rescued by transfection with a p65 expression construct, suggesting an inverse relationship between NF-κB and susceptibility to the cytotoxicity of NO/O2. Despite the reduced NF-κB activity in cells exposed to NO ± O2, IκBα was degraded, suggesting that pathways regulating the steady-state levels of IκB were not involved. However, exposure to NO/O2caused a marked reduction in nuclear localization and an increase in protein carbonyl formation of NF-κB p65 subunit. These results suggest that NO/O2-induced apoptosis occurs by suppressing NF-κB activity. Prolonged exposure to NO/O2 causes synergistic lung injury and death of lung epithelial cells. To explore the mechanisms involved, oxygen-resistant HeLa-80 cells were exposed to NO ± O2. This apoptosis was associated with a synergistic suppression of NF-κB activity. Cells lacking functional NF-κB p65 subunit were more sensitive to NO/O2 than their wild type counterparts. This injury was partially rescued by transfection with a p65 expression construct, suggesting an inverse relationship between NF-κB and susceptibility to the cytotoxicity of NO/O2. These results suggest that NO/O2-induced apoptosis occurs by suppressing NF-κB activity. inhaled nitric oxide reactive oxygen species phosphatidylserine fluorescein isothiocyanate propidium iodide phosphate-buffered saline 4′,6-diamidine-2-phenylindole dihydrochloride cytomagalovirus (Z)-1-[2-(2-aminoethyl)-N-(2-ammonioethyl)amino]diazen-1-ium-1,2-diolate reactive nitrogen species tumor necrosis factor Inhaled nitric oxide (iNO)1 is used clinically as a therapeutic modality to selectively manipulate the pulmonary vasculature for the treatment of persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn. In most cases, these patients receive simultaneous oxygen therapy with supraphysiological concentrations of oxygen. However, studies have shown that prolonged exposure to the combination of NO and hyperoxia (NO/O2) causes significantly more lung injury than hyperoxia alone in several animal models, including piglets (1Robbins C.G. Davis J.M. Merritt T.A. Amirkhanian J.D. Sahgal N. Morin F.C. Horowitz S. Am. J. Physiol. 1995; 269: L545-L550PubMed Google Scholar) and rats (2Nader N.D. Knight P.R. Bobela I. Davidson B.A. Johnson K.J. Morin F. Anesthesiology. 1999; 91: 741-749Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar). This increased lung injury is associated with increased apoptosis of lung cells (3Ekekezie I.I. Thibeault D.W. Zwick D.L. Rezaiekhaligh M.H. Mabry S.M. Morgan R.E. Norberg M. Truog W.E. Biol. Neonate. 2000; 77: 37-44Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). We have previously shown that exposure of cultured pulmonary cells to NO and hyperoxia causes a synergistic cytotoxicity (4Narula P., Xu, J. Kazzaz J.A. Robbins C.G. Davis J.M. Horowitz S. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: L411-L416PubMed Google Scholar), similar to that observed in lungs of exposed animals. In addition, significantly more apoptosis has been found when isolated human neutrophils and primary cultures of normal human lung fibroblasts were exposed to NO/O2 than those exposed to O2alone (5Fortenberry J.D. Owens M.L. Brown M.R. Atkinson D. Brown L.A. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1998; 18: 421-428Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 6Raghuram N. Fortenberry J.D. Owens M.L. Brown L.A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1999; 262: 685-691Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). These studies suggest that prolonged exposure to the combination of NO and hyperoxia has direct toxic effects on lung cells and the resulting injury and death of pulmonary cells may lead to impaired pulmonary function and lung injury. NF-κB is a key redox-sensitive transcription factor in inflammatory diseases, where it regulates the inflammatory response by modulating the gene expression of cytokines, chemokines, and adhesion molecules (7Yamamoto Y. Gaynor R.B. J. Clin. Invest. 2001; 107: 135-142Crossref PubMed Scopus (1352) Google Scholar, 8Tak P.P. Firestein G.S. J. Clin. Invest. 2001; 107: 7-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (3287) Google Scholar). In addition, NF-κB has been shown to play a pivotal role in mediating cell proliferation and survival against a variety of cell death stimuli, including oxidative and nitrosative stress (9Mattson M.P. Culmsee C., Yu, Z. Camandola S. J. Neurochem. 2000; 74: 443-456Crossref PubMed Scopus (434) Google Scholar, 10Mattson M.P. Goodman Y. Luo H., Fu, W. Furukawa K. J. Neurosci. Res. 1997; 49: 681-697Crossref PubMed Scopus (523) Google Scholar, 11Ibe W. Bartels W. Lindemann S. Grosser T. Buerke M. Boissel J.P. Meyer J. Darius H. Cell Physiol. Cell Death Differ. 2001; 8: 144-151Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 13Nakshatri H. Bhat-Nakshatri P. Martin D.A. Goulet Jr., R.J. Sledge Jr., G.W. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1997; 17: 3629-3639Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 14Raziuddin A. Court D. Sarkar F.H. Liu Y.L. Kung H. Raziuddin R. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 15715-15720Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 15Shattuck-Brandt R.L. Richmond A. Cancer Res. 1997; 57: 3032-3039PubMed Google Scholar). NO has also been shown to be closely associated with NF-κB. NF-κB is an essential transcription factor for the production of endogenous NO and acts by mediating the gene expression of iNOS (16Xie Q.W. Kashiwabara Y. Nathan C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 4705-4708Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Marshall H.E. Stamler J.S. Am. J. Respir. Cell Mol. Biol. 1999; 21: 296-297Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar). Exogenous NO can also affect NF-κB transcriptional activity by directly interacting with or modulating upstream pathways of its activation (18Bogdan C. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 66-75Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (457) Google Scholar). The role of exogenous NO in modulating NF-κB activity in vitro is cell line-, NO donor-, and dose-dependent (18Bogdan C. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 66-75Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (457) Google Scholar, 19Connelly L. Palacios-Callender M. Ameixa C. Moncada S. Hobbs A.J. J. Immunol. 2001; 166: 3873-3881Crossref PubMed Scopus (289) Google Scholar). In human peripheral blood mononuclear cells, NF-κB is activated by NO (20Deora A.A. Win T. Vanhaesebroeck B. Lander H.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 29923-29928Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (167) Google Scholar), whereas, in human and bovine vascular endothelial cells, exogenous NO inhibits tumor necrosis factor-mediated NF-κB activation (21Matthews J.R. Botting C.H. Panico M. Morris H.R. Hay R.T. Nucleic Acids Res. 1996; 24: 2236-2242Crossref PubMed Scopus (461) Google Scholar, 22Spiecker M. Peng H.B. Liao J.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 30969-30974Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (230) Google Scholar). All normal cells are sensitive to hyperoxia and suffer oxygen toxicity. Reactive oxygen species (ROS), especially superoxide, are thought to have a pivotal role in oxygen toxicity. In the presence of ROS, NO can form highly reactive species, including peroxynitrite, resulting in enhanced cytotoxicity (18Bogdan C. Trends Cell Biol. 2001; 11: 66-75Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (457) Google Scholar). To delineate the role of the pathways induced by hyperoxia in the absence of oxygen toxicity, we utilized HeLa-80 cells, a mutant oxygen-resistant cell line. HeLa-80 cells, derived from HeLa cells, a cervical epithelial cell line, are capable of stable proliferation in 80% O2, a lethal dose to many other cell types (23Joenje H. Gille J.J. Oostra A.B. Van der Valk P. Lab. Invest. 1985; 52: 420-428PubMed Google Scholar, 24Joenje H. Gille J. Horowitz S., Li, Z. Whyzmuzis C. Massaro D. Oxygen Regulation of Genes and Metabolism. Marcel Dekker, New York1997: 67-73Google Scholar). In this study, we examined the cytotoxicity resulting from the exposure to NO ± O2 in HeLa-80 cells, determined the mode of cell death, and examined the role of NF-κB regulation in the cytotoxicity of NO/O2. HeLa-80 cells and human lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells were grown and maintained at 37 °C as described previously (25Franek W.R. Horowitz S. Stansberry L. Kazzaz J.A. Koo H.C., Li, Y. Arita Y. Davis J.M. Mantell A.S. Scott W. Mantell L.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 569-575Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). NIH 3T3 wild type and RelA−/− cells (26Beg A.A. Baltimore D. Science. 1996; 274: 782-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (2935) Google Scholar) were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (Invitrogen) supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum and 1% penicillin-streptomycin in 95% room air and 5% CO2. Cells were exposed to 0.5–7.5 mm DETA NONOate, a NO donor from Cayman Chemical, Ann Arbor, MI, in the presence or absence of 80% O2 for up to 6 days as previously described (4Narula P., Xu, J. Kazzaz J.A. Robbins C.G. Davis J.M. Horowitz S. Am. J. Physiol. 1998; 274: L411-L416PubMed Google Scholar, 25Franek W.R. Horowitz S. Stansberry L. Kazzaz J.A. Koo H.C., Li, Y. Arita Y. Davis J.M. Mantell A.S. Scott W. Mantell L.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 569-575Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (56) Google Scholar). Media and gases were refreshed daily. Cell death/viability was determined by trypan blue exclusion or 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide assays (27Carmichael J. de Graff W.G. Gazdar A.F. Minna J.D. Mitchell J.B. To determine if the synergistic cytotoxicity induced by the exposure to NO/O2 is primarily due to oxygen toxicity, HeLa-80 cells were exposed to 80% O2 and 0.5 mm DETA NONOate either separately or in combination. These cells were viable and proliferated for 6 days when cultured either in room air or 80% O2 (Fig.1 A). However, a decrease of cell viability was observed in cells exposed to NO/O2 after 5 days, whereas cells exposed to NO alone were alive after 6 days (Fig.1 A). To determine whether there is an increase in cell death in cells exposed to NO/O2 than to NO, we determined the cytotoxicity of DETA NONOate in HeLa-80 cells. Exposure to up to 2.5 mm DETA NONOate for 24 h caused little or no significant cell death, whereas 5–7.5 mm DETA NONOate induced marked cell death (data not shown). We therefore used 5 mm DETA NONOate in the subsequent experiments. After 24-h exposure to 5 mm NO, the amount of cell death was increased to 24 ± 3.6%, whereas 81 ± 8.1% (p < 0.05) cells exposed to both 80% O2 and 5 mmDETA NONOate were dead (Fig. 1 B). Results derived from 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide analysis further validated these results (data not shown). Because HeLa-80 cells tolerate 80% O2, these data demonstrate that synergistic cytotoxicity of NO and hyperoxia is not due to pleiotropic oxygen toxicity. The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) is a ligand-activated member of the basic helix-loop-helix period aryl hydrocarbon nuclear translocator single-minded (PAS) transcription factor family. This receptor has been shown to be important in various aspects of growth and development as demonstrated by AhR-null mice. A yeast two-hybrid screen of a mouse embryonic day 11 library for AhR-interacting proteins revealed Nedd8 as a candidate. The interaction was confirmed in a cell-free system and in mammalian cells by co-immunoprecipitation; however, in vitro neddylation assays showed that Nedd8 does not covalently modify AhR. Transfection of Nedd8 into a cell line stably transfected with a dioxin response element linked to a chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter gene demonstrated that Nedd8 amplified ligand-induced transcription. Deletion of the Gly-76 residue in the carboxyl terminus of Nedd8 abolished this effect and prevented AhR-Nedd8 interaction. Nedd8 overexpression also resulted in accumulation of AhR protein in the nucleus, independent of exogenous ligand. These studies demonstrate that the AhR interacts with Nedd8 and suggest that this interaction enhances the transcriptional activity of the receptor, perhaps involving increased nuclear accumulation or retention. Immunohistochemistry performed on embryonic day 11.5 mouse sections indicated Nedd8 and AhR localize to overlapping areas in the heart and spinal ganglia, raising the possibility that this interaction may play a role in organogenesis. The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) 1The abbreviations used are: AhR, aryl hydrocarbon receptor; TCDD, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin; DRE, dioxin response element; ARNT, AhR nuclear translocator; HA, hemagglutinin; bHLH, basic helix-loop-helix; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; E, embryonic day; Cul, cullin; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; E1, ubiquitin-activating enzyme; E2, ubiquitin conjugating enzyme; ER, estrogen receptor; HIF-1α, hypoxia-inducible factor 1α 1The abbreviations used are: AhR, aryl hydrocarbon receptor; TCDD, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin; DRE, dioxin response element; ARNT, AhR nuclear translocator; HA, hemagglutinin; bHLH, basic helix-loop-helix; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; E, embryonic day; Cul, cullin; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; E1, ubiquitin-activating enzyme; E2, ubiquitin conjugating enzyme; ER, estrogen receptor; HIF-1α, hypoxia-inducible factor 1αis a ligand-activated transcription factor belonging to the basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH)/period aryl hydrocarbon nuclear translocator single-minded (PAS) family of heterodimeric transcriptional regulators. The biological effects of 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin (TCDD) and related environmental contaminants are mediated by AhR and promote carcinogenesis, immune suppression, hepatotoxicity, cardiac toxicity, and impairment of reproductive function (as reviewed by Hankinson (1Hankinson O. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1995; 35: 307-340Crossref PubMed Scopus (1421) Google Scholar)). Unliganded AhR resides in the cytoplasm as part of an inactive multiprotein complex that contains 90-kDa heat shock proteins (HSP90), immunophilin-like protein XAP2 (also known as AhR-associated protein 9 (ARA9) or AhR-interacting protein (AIP)), and p23 (2Petrulis J.R. Hord N.G. Perdew G.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37448-37453Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 3Ma Q. Whitlock Jr., J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 8878-8884Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (361) Google Scholar). Upon binding ligand, the two HSP90 molecules dissociate, and the receptor translocates to the nucleus and heterodimerizes with another bHLH member protein, the aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator (ARNT) protein. This protein complex then binds to cognate regulatory elements, referred to as dioxin-responsive elements (DREs), located in the promoter region of a number of known target genes, which include the phase I cytochromes P4501A1,P4501A2, and P4501B1. Activated AhR is exported from the nucleus for degradation in the cytosol by the ubiquitin/proteasome pathway (4Roberts B.J. Whitelaw M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36351-36356Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar).The molecular events leading to the activation of AhR in the presence of TCDD are generally well understood in a toxicological context. However, AhR signaling pathways in the absence of exogenous ligands remain relatively unknown. The phenotypes of three independent mouse strains with targeted disruption of the AhR strongly suggest a physiological role for this receptor in homeostasis, liver development, and immune system function as well as a role in cell proliferation and differentiation (5Fernandez-Salguero P. Pineau T. Hilbert D.M. McPhail T. Lee S.S. Kimura S. Nebert D.W. Rudikoff S. Ward J.M. Gonzalez F.J. Science. 1995; 268: 722-726Crossref PubMed Scopus (934) Google Scholar, 6Schmidt J.V., Su, G.H. Reddy J.K. Simon M.C. Bradfield C.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 6731-6736Crossref PubMed Scopus (742) Google Scholar). The AhR is highly conserved in a number of species including fruit flies, zebrafish, worms, chickens, mice, and humans. The function and regulation of AhR during development are currently being addressed in each of these model systems.In an effort to identify proteins that are a part of the AhR complex and that might modulate its activity, we used a yeast two-hybrid system to screen for proteins that interact with the AhR. Studies of the developmental expression of AhR in C57BL/6 mouse embryos using in situ hybridization and/or immunohistochemical analysis have shown that AhR expression is not detectable until embryonic day (E) 10 onward, suggesting that this is the first time during development that AhR protein is expressed (7Abbott B.D. Birnbaum L.S. Perdew G.H. Dev. Dyn. 1995; 204: 133-143Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). We therefore used a mouse E11 cDNA library in our yeast two-hybrid screen. We report here the isolation of a cDNA clone encoding Nedd8 (neurally expressed developmentally down-regulated protein 8) that interacts with AhR in a ligand-independent manner.Nedd8 is a ubiquitin-like protein, initially identified by Kumaret al. (8Kumar S. Tomooka Y. Noda M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 185: 1155-1161Crossref PubMed Scopus (442) Google Scholar) in a subtractive cloning approach to identify genes involved in the development of the mammalian central nervous system, that covalently modifies target proteins that reside in the nucleus. Known targets of Nedd8 modulation include p27kip1and all members of the human cullin family of proteins (9Hori T. Osaka F. Chiba T. Miyamoto C. Okabayashi K. Shimbara N. Kato S. Tanaka K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 6829-6834Crossref PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar). In this study we provide novel evidence showing that Nedd8 enhances the action of the AhR.DISCUSSIONThis study identifies Nedd8 as a novel interacting partner of the AhR. This interaction, initially identified by our yeast two-hybrid screen, was confirmed both in a cell-free system and in mammalian cells by immunoprecipitation and occurred independent of exogenous ligand. Moreover, the demonstration that endogenously expressed Nedd8 and AhR interact in T47D human breast cancer cells clearly establishes this ubiquitin-like protein as a physiologically relevant partner and potential modulator of AhR.Nedd8 is the mammalian functional homologue of Rub1 in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The ligation of Nedd8/Rub1 to proteins is likely to have important growth-regulatory roles in plants, mammals, and presumably many other organisms (18Hochstrasser M. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 901-907Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Nedd8 conjugation involves a pathway that parallels that of ubiquitination, including activation by a distinct E1-like enzyme and conjugation mediated by a dedicated E2 enzyme (20Whitby F.G. Xia G. Pickart C.M. Hill C.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34983-34991Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). The Nedd8 modification (neddylation) pathway utilizes a unique activating enzyme complex (UBA3/APP-BP1) and conjugation enzyme (UBC12). In mammalian cells, Nedd8 has been shown to modify a limited subset of cellular proteins in vivo, all of which belong to the cullin family. Human cul-1 is a major component of the SCF complex that is responsible for ubiquitination of a multitude of proteins that regulate various biologically important processes such as cell cycle progression and signal transduction (21Deshaies R.J. Jacks T. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 705-707Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 22Pickart C.M. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 499-504Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar). These include Iκβα, β-catenin, and p27 (23Pagano M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 1067-1075Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar, 24Laney J.D. Hochstrasser M. Cell. 1999; 97: 427-430Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar).One of the speculated functions of AhR is to regulate gene expression in a ligand-dependent fashion; therefore, we investigated the effect of overexpression of Nedd8 on the transcriptional activity of AhR. Our data demonstrate Nedd8 overexpression enhanced AhR-mediated transactivation of a DRE-tk-CAT reporter gene in a dose-dependent manner in cells exposed to TCDD. Interestingly, a similar pattern was observed in the absence of TCDD treatment, suggesting that NEDD8 may promote AhR action in the absence of ligand or enhance its action in the presence of ligand endogenous to the culture system. The mechanism by which Nedd8 amplifies the transcriptional activity of AhR remains to be determined. One possibility is that it functions as a nuclear receptor coactivator, bridging the AhR complex with general transcriptional factors and/or histone acetyltransferases. Alternatively, association with Nedd8 could influence the nuclear localization and/or stability of the receptor complex and prolong the action of the AhR complex at the DRE.Interaction of Nedd8 has not been reported previously for any of the nuclear receptors or bHLH/PAS family members. However, UBA3 was recently shown to interact directly with both estrogen receptor (ER)-α and -β in a ligand-dependent manner and to suppress ER-mediated transactivation in mammalian cells (25Fan M. Interestingly, the interaction of Nedd8 and AhR was identified in screening a mouse day E11 library. At this point of development, AhR is ubiquitously expressed, whereas Nedd8 protein appears to have a more restricted pattern of expression. The expression of AhR in tissues without Nedd8 expression indicates that interaction with Nedd8 is not essential for the actions of this transcription factor. However, the overlap of expression in the heart and spinal ganglia at E10−E12 suggests that the interaction of these two proteins may play an important role in cardiogenesis and neural development.At present, the function of the AhR and Nedd8 interaction during development is not clear. Based on our data, we propose that Nedd8 regulates the activation of AhR and AhR-mediated signal transduction by enhancing accumulation of the receptor in the cell nucleus. Additionally, by acting to facilitate ubiquitination, this association could assist in receptor turnover. Thus the interaction with Nedd8 could represent a developmentally important, tissue-specific posttranslational modification of the AhR. Moreover, this interaction may be involved in modulating the toxicological effects of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Additional studies of the functional interaction of Nedd8 with AhR should enhance our understanding of AhR functionin vivo. The aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR) 1The abbreviations used are: AhR, aryl hydrocarbon receptor; TCDD, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin; DRE, dioxin response element; ARNT, AhR nuclear translocator; HA, hemagglutinin; bHLH, basic helix-loop-helix; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; E, embryonic day; Cul, cullin; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; E1, ubiquitin-activating enzyme; E2, ubiquitin conjugating enzyme; ER, estrogen receptor; HIF-1α, hypoxia-inducible factor 1α 1The abbreviations used are: AhR, aryl hydrocarbon receptor; TCDD, 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin; DRE, dioxin response element; ARNT, AhR nuclear translocator; HA, hemagglutinin; bHLH, basic helix-loop-helix; CAT, chloramphenicol acetyltransferase; E, embryonic day; Cul, cullin; PBS, phosphate-buffered saline; E1, ubiquitin-activating enzyme; E2, ubiquitin conjugating enzyme; ER, estrogen receptor; HIF-1α, hypoxia-inducible factor 1αis a ligand-activated transcription factor belonging to the basic helix-loop-helix (bHLH)/period aryl hydrocarbon nuclear translocator single-minded (PAS) family of heterodimeric transcriptional regulators. The biological effects of 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-(p)-dioxin (TCDD) and related environmental contaminants are mediated by AhR and promote carcinogenesis, immune suppression, hepatotoxicity, cardiac toxicity, and impairment of reproductive function (as reviewed by Hankinson (1Hankinson O. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1995; 35: 307-340Crossref PubMed Scopus (1421) Google Scholar)). Unliganded AhR resides in the cytoplasm as part of an inactive multiprotein complex that contains 90-kDa heat shock proteins (HSP90), immunophilin-like protein XAP2 (also known as AhR-associated protein 9 (ARA9) or AhR-interacting protein (AIP)), and p23 (2Petrulis J.R. Hord N.G. Perdew G.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 37448-37453Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (85) Google Scholar, 3Ma Q. Whitlock Jr., J.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 8878-8884Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (361) Google Scholar). Upon binding ligand, the two HSP90 molecules dissociate, and the receptor translocates to the nucleus and heterodimerizes with another bHLH member protein, the aryl hydrocarbon receptor nuclear translocator (ARNT) protein. This protein complex then binds to cognate regulatory elements, referred to as dioxin-responsive elements (DREs), located in the promoter region of a number of known target genes, which include the phase I cytochromes P4501A1,P4501A2, and P4501B1. Activated AhR is exported from the nucleus for degradation in the cytosol by the ubiquitin/proteasome pathway (4Roberts B.J. Whitelaw M.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 36351-36356Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). The molecular events leading to the activation of AhR in the presence of TCDD are generally well understood in a toxicological context. However, AhR signaling pathways in the absence of exogenous ligands remain relatively unknown. The phenotypes of three independent mouse strains with targeted disruption of the AhR strongly suggest a physiological role for this receptor in homeostasis, liver development, and immune system function as well as a role in cell proliferation and differentiation (5Fernandez-Salguero P. Pineau T. Hilbert D.M. McPhail T. Lee S.S. Kimura S. Nebert D.W. Rudikoff S. Ward J.M. Gonzalez F.J. Science. 1995; 268: 722-726Crossref PubMed Scopus (934) Google Scholar, 6Schmidt J.V., Su, G.H. Reddy J.K. Simon M.C. Bradfield C.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 6731-6736Crossref PubMed Scopus (742) Google Scholar). The AhR is highly conserved in a number of species including fruit flies, zebrafish, worms, chickens, mice, and humans. The function and regulation of AhR during development are currently being addressed in each of these model systems. In an effort to identify proteins that are a part of the AhR complex and that might modulate its activity, we used a yeast two-hybrid system to screen for proteins that interact with the AhR. Studies of the developmental expression of AhR in C57BL/6 mouse embryos using in situ hybridization and/or immunohistochemical analysis have shown that AhR expression is not detectable until embryonic day (E) 10 onward, suggesting that this is the first time during development that AhR protein is expressed (7Abbott B.D. Birnbaum L.S. Perdew G.H. Dev. Dyn. 1995; 204: 133-143Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). We therefore used a mouse E11 cDNA library in our yeast two-hybrid screen. We report here the isolation of a cDNA clone encoding Nedd8 (neurally expressed developmentally down-regulated protein 8) that interacts with AhR in a ligand-independent manner. Nedd8 is a ubiquitin-like protein, initially identified by Kumaret al. (8Kumar S. Tomooka Y. Noda M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 185: 1155-1161Crossref PubMed Scopus (442) Google Scholar) in a subtractive cloning approach to identify genes involved in the development of the mammalian central nervous system, that covalently modifies target proteins that reside in the nucleus. Known targets of Nedd8 modulation include p27kip1and all members of the human cullin family of proteins (9Hori T. Osaka F. Chiba T. Miyamoto C. Okabayashi K. Shimbara N. Kato S. Tanaka K. Oncogene. 1999; 18: 6829-6834Crossref PubMed Scopus (243) Google Scholar). In this study we provide novel evidence showing that Nedd8 enhances the action of the AhR. DISCUSSIONThis study identifies Nedd8 as a novel interacting partner of the AhR. This interaction, initially identified by our yeast two-hybrid screen, was confirmed both in a cell-free system and in mammalian cells by immunoprecipitation and occurred independent of exogenous ligand. Moreover, the demonstration that endogenously expressed Nedd8 and AhR interact in T47D human breast cancer cells clearly establishes this ubiquitin-like protein as a physiologically relevant partner and potential modulator of AhR.Nedd8 is the mammalian functional homologue of Rub1 in the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae. The ligation of Nedd8/Rub1 to proteins is likely to have important growth-regulatory roles in plants, mammals, and presumably many other organisms (18Hochstrasser M. Genes Dev. 1998; 12: 901-907Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). Nedd8 conjugation involves a pathway that parallels that of ubiquitination, including activation by a distinct E1-like enzyme and conjugation mediated by a dedicated E2 enzyme (20Whitby F.G. Xia G. Pickart C.M. Hill C.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 34983-34991Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar). The Nedd8 modification (neddylation) pathway utilizes a unique activating enzyme complex (UBA3/APP-BP1) and conjugation enzyme (UBC12). In mammalian cells, Nedd8 has been shown to modify a limited subset of cellular proteins in vivo, all of which belong to the cullin family. Human cul-1 is a major component of the SCF complex that is responsible for ubiquitination of a multitude of proteins that regulate various biologically important processes such as cell cycle progression and signal transduction (21Deshaies R.J. Jacks T. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 705-707Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 22Pickart C.M. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 499-504Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (335) Google Scholar). These include Iκβα, β-catenin, and p27 (23Pagano M. FASEB J. 1997; 11: 1067-1075Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar, 24Laney J.D. Hochstrasser M. Cell. 1999; 97: 427-430Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (389) Google Scholar).One of the speculated functions of AhR is to regulate gene expression in a ligand-dependent fashion; therefore, we investigated the effect of overexpression of Nedd8 on the transcriptional activity of AhR. Our data demonstrate Nedd8 overexpression enhanced AhR-mediated transactivation of a DRE-tk-CAT reporter gene in a dose-dependent manner in cells exposed to TCDD. Interestingly, a similar pattern was observed in the absence of TCDD treatment, suggesting that NEDD8 may promote AhR action in the absence of ligand or enhance its action in the presence of ligand endogenous to the culture system. The mechanism by which Nedd8 amplifies the transcriptional activity of AhR remains to be determined. One possibility is that it functions as a nuclear receptor coactivator, bridging the AhR complex with general transcriptional factors and/or histone acetyltransferases. Alternatively, association with Nedd8 could influence the nuclear localization and/or stability of the receptor complex and prolong the action of the AhR complex at the DRE.Interaction of Nedd8 has not been reported previously for any of the nuclear receptors or bHLH/PAS family members.
